Table 5 Catalyst Solvent Conversion (%) Selectivity (%) MCM-I-mim - 99 > 99 MCM-I-mim toluene 88 > 99 MCM-Br-mim - 97 > 99 MCM-Br-mim toluene 81 > 99 MCM-Cl-mim toluene 10 > 99 Heterogeneous catalysts based on salts of N-heterocycles for cycloaddition of CO2 Zitova Kateřina Zítová Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Conceptualization Zelinkova Karolína Zelinková Visualization Investigation Formal analysis Vyskočilova Eliška Vyskočilová Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Supervision ⁎ Department of Organic Technology, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Technická 5, Praha 6, 16628, Czech Republic Department of Organic Technology, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague Technická 5, Praha 6 16628 Czech Republic Department of Organic Technology, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Technická 5, Praha 6, 166 28, Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author. In this paper, the novel materials based on MCM-41-supported salts of N-heterocycles were prepared, and characterized by available methods (EA, DRUV, XRD, TGA, and nitrogen physisorption). The prepared materials were used as catalysts for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to epoxides. The model reaction for this study was the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide leading to the synthesis of styrene carbonate. The influence of the halogen type and N-heterocycle used was observed. The cycloaddition reactions using the prepared catalysts proved to be highly selective (almost 100 % in all cases). The most efficient catalyst was composed of (3-iodopropyl)trimethoxysilane and 1-methylimidazole, forming MCM-41supporting 1-methylimidazolium iodide with the conversion of styrene oxide 99 % (120 °C, 1.2 MPa, solvent-free, 5 h). Graphical Abstract Keywords Cycloaddition Carbon dioxide N-heterocycle-based salt MCM-41 Styrene oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Salts of nitrogen-based compounds represent an interesting group of compounds with a wide range of applications in chemistry, from organic synthesis to electrochemistry and separation processes [1,2]. These salts are characterized by their tunable properties. Ion exchange allows changing properties such as viscosity, hydrophobicity, acidity, and melting point [3]. A particularly promising application is their use as organocatalysts. Salts of nitrogen-based compounds have been extensively studied as high-efficient catalysts for diverse chemical transformations, including Knoevenagel condensation, aldol condensation, Friedel-Crafts reactions, and the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide [4,5]. The cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to epoxides leads to the formation of cyclic carbonates. Cyclic carbonates represent compounds with high boiling points and low toxicity. They are excellent aprotic polar solvents, and they are widely used as fine chemical intermediates, and as monomers for the synthesis of polymers [6–8]. In addition, they are used in the production of lithium batteries, resins, and fuel additives [9,10]. The process of cycloaddition has attracted much attention due to the avoiding the use of phosgene in the preparation of cyclic carbonates, but also due to the economic and environmental benefits arising from converting carbon dioxide into valuable chemical compounds. Therefore, new materials catalyzing this transformation are still being developed. The most used catalysts for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide from a group of quaternary ammonium salts is tetrabutylammonium bromide [9,11]. Metal oxides [12], metal halides [13], and imidazolium salts [14] are also mentioned homogeneous catalysts. However, with current demands in the field of sustainable chemistry and environmentally benign processes, it is an advantage to use a supported homogeneous catalyst, which can be easily separated and reused. The most frequently mentioned heterogeneous catalysts for this type of reaction can be divided into two groups [15]. The first group is represented by the immobilization of active moieties, or homogeneous catalysts (especially ionic liquids and ammonium salts) on solid supports [15–17]. Silicate materials and polymers represent traditional solid supports. The second group includes the preparation of porous networks, which are mainly metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [18,19] and porous organic polymers (POPs) [20,21]. The importance of enantiopure compounds that can be obtained in processes using chiral catalysts is also increasingly discussed. The literature describes chiral ionic liquids [22–24] and metal complexes [24–26] as catalysts for the asymmetric cycloaddition of carbon dioxide. In our previous work [27], we prepared and tested a catalyst based on MCM-41-supported pyridinium salt. Using this type of catalyst in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide, the yield of styrene carbonate was up to 93 % (120 °C, 1.2 MPa,5 h). In this work, we focus on the study of different N-heterocyclic compounds and the comparison of their catalytic activity. The asymmetric cycloaddition of carbon dioxide using a chiral 4-substituted pyridinium catalyst was also discussed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Pyridine (99,8 %), 3-iodopropyltrimethoxysilane (>95 %), 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane (95 %), tetraethoxysilane (98 %), 1-methylimidazole (>99 %), 3-methylpyrazole (97 %), and hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (>98 %) were purchased from Merck. Dichloromethane (p.a.) and toluene (p.a.) were obtained from Lach:ner. Pyrimidine (>98 %), quinoline (>95 %), 1,2,4-triazole (>99 %), 3-bromopropyltrimethoxysilane (>98 %), (S)-4-(1-hydroxyethyl)pyridine (>97 %), and styrene oxide (>98 %) were purchased from TCI. Ammonia (26 % aqueous solution) was purchased from Penta. Demineralized water was taken from UCT Prague sources (< 1 μS/mL). 2.2 Preparation of MCM-41 MCM-41 was prepared following the standard procedure. First, 2.4 g of hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide was dissolved in demineralized water (120 mL) preheated to 35 °C. After dissolution, 10 mL of 26 % aqueous ammonia solution was added. After approximately 5 minutes, 10 mL of tetraethoxysilane was added and the resulting suspension was subsequently stirred for 24 hours at room temperature. After 24 hours the suspension was filtered and the solid was washed by demineralized water (3 ×10 mL) and ethanol (3 ×10 mL) and dried at 100 °C for 1 hour. This was followed by calcination at 550 °C under nitrogen atmosphere (2 h) and then in an oxygen atmosphere (18 h). Subsequently, the product was stirred in demineralized water for 20 h in order to increase the amount of hydroxyl groups. The solid was filtered and dried at 100 °C for 24 h. 2.3 Preparation of catalysts The modification of MCM-41 surface was performed by mixing of 4 mmol of silane (3-iodopropyltrimethoxysilane, 3-bromopropyltrimethoxysilane, or 3-chloropropyltriehoxysilane), 13 mL of toluene and 1 g of MCM-41. The mixture was stirred under reflux (120 °C) for 2 hours. The solid was filtered and washed with toluene (3 ×10 mL). Afterwards, quaternization reaction was performed with a nitrogenous heterocycle. In quaternization, modified MCM-41, 8.4 mmol of nitrogen compound and 20 mL of toluene were mixed. The reaction mixture was heated to a temperature of 120 °C and stirred under reflux on a magnetic stirrer for 24 hours. Subsequently, the product was filtered, washed with toluene and dichloromethane and dried (100 °C) overnight. Based on the halogen and the N-heterocycle used, the materials were labeled as follows: MCM-X-R, where X represents halogen (I, Br, Cl) and R represents N-heterocycle (py=pyridine, pyrim=pyrimidine, quin=quinoline, mim=1-methylimidazole, mpyr=3-methylpyrazole, triz=1,2,4-triazole, (S)-py=(S)-4-(1-hydroxyethyl)pyridine). 2.4 Characterization Elemental analysis (EA) (C,H,N) was performed using Elementar Vario EL Cube. The accuracy of the method is established by the manufacturer for the simultaneous analysis of 5 mg of the standard 4-amino-benzene sulfonic acid in the CHNS mode to < 0.1 % abs. The halogen content (I,Br,Cl) was determined by the argentometric titration analysis modified for low sample loading. Elemental analysis was used to confirm the presence and quantification of the heterocycle in the material structure. Thermogravimetric analysis data (TG) were obtained on TA Discovery TGA under the following conditions: 30–550 °C, 10 °C·min−1, nitrogen atmosphere. UV/Vis in the DR mode was performed on Shimadzu UV2600i using an integrating sphere. Nitrogen sorption measurements were carried out on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 V300H. The specific surfaces and pore volume calculations used BET/BJH equations. The structure was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in the low angle mode at room temperature on PANalytical X´Pert PRO. The degree of quaternization (DQ) was calculated as follows DQ = n ( X ) n ( N ) . DQ is defined as the ratio of the moles of halogen to the moles of nitrogen present in the prepared material. It serves as a parameter indicating the percentage of salt formation. Notably, when using heterocycles such as 1-methylimidazole, pyrimidine, 3-methylpyrazole, and 1,2,4-triazole, a higher number of nitrogen atoms in its structure was taken into consideration. Turnover number (TON) was calculated as ratio of moles of converted styrene oxide to moles of onium sites. The amount of onium sites was quantified based on elemental analysis and calculation of the quaternization degree. 2.5 Catalytic testing The catalytic activity was verified on the model reaction cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide. Catalytic experiments were conducted in a stainless-steel autoclave Parr 4842 (50 mL). The catalyst (150 mg) was dosed to a solution of styrene oxide (10 mmol) and solvent (toluene, 25 mL) in the reactor. In a solvent-free arrangement, catalyst (150 mg) was added to the reactor together with styrene oxide (10 mmol). The autoclave was sealed, washed with carbon dioxide, and preheated to 120 °C. Upon reaching the temperature, the reaction started by increasing pressure to 1.2 MPa by carbon dioxide. Samples taken were centrifuged to remove the solid catalyst and analyzed by GC Shimadzu 2010 (FID, non-polar column ZB-5). For the product identification, the GC MS Shimadzu 2010 (non-polar column DB-5ms, quadrupole detector) was used. 3 Results and discussion A wide range of nitrogen-based heterocycles supported on MCM-41 was used for the testing in model cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene carbonate. The detail characterization describing the properties of prepared material was performed in the first part of the study. The attachment of catalyst on MCM-41 was enabled by the quaternization of nitrogen atom with halogen atom. Halogen atom was present on the MCM-41 after the modification by halogenopropyltri(m)ethoxysilane. The procedure of MCM-41 modification was described in the experimental part, using the already known procedure used in our previous study [27]. The scheme of the material preparation using 1-methylimidazole as an example is in the Fig. 1. The nitrogen-based heterocycles were of three types – with one nitrogen in the molecule (pyridine, quinoline), with two nitrogen atoms in the molecule (pyrimidine, 1-methylimidazole, 3-methylpyrazole) and with three nitrogen atoms in the molecule (1,2,4-triazole). Moreover, two potentially chiral catalysts were prepared by the same procedure as mentioned in the experimental part using chiral nitrogen-based heterocycle (S)-4-(1-hydroxyethyl)pyridine. All used heterocycles are depicted in the Fig. 2. Following second part dealt with the influence of the prepared materials on the reaction course of carbon dioxide cycloaddition to styrene oxide, and the evaluation of their catalytic activity based on their properties. 3.1 Material characterization Available characterization techniques were used for the study of the successful attachment of heterocycle on halogen modified MCM-41 (EA, DRUV, XRD), stability of the prepared materials (TGA) and textural properties (nitrogen physisorption). The details about characterization of halogen modified MCM-41 were given elsewhere [27]. Elemental analysis ( Table 1) confirmed the presence of halogens that were attached to the MCM-41 surface through a propyl linker, and the presence and the amount of a nitrogen heterocycles in the structure after quaternization reaction. The amount of attached halogen and heterocycle varied based on the structure of the heterocycle being used. The N-heterocycles used can be divided into 3 groups according to the number of nitrogen atoms in their structure. This also affects the preparation of the required quaternary salt. Using 1-methylimidazole, 3-methylpyrazole, pyrimidine, and 1,2,4-triazole, there are more options for the attachment of heterocycle to the linker Fig. 3. From the structure of 1-methylimidazole, we can see that the attachment of halogen to both nitrogen atoms formed a quaternary salt (Fig. 3(C,D)). The possibility of pyrimidine attachment to the surface of MCM-41 simultaneously via both nitrogen atoms was also considered for the material MCM-I-pyrim (Fig. 3(B)). On the other hand, with methylpyrazole, while the attachment of propyl linker to the tertiary nitrogen led to the salt formation (Fig. 3(E)), attachment to the secondary nitrogen did not lead to a formation of quaternary salt and halide ion left the propyl linker in the form of HX (Fig. 3(F)). It is obvious that the second possibility is undesirable due to the importance of the halide presence for the opening of the epoxy ring. The same substitution reaction could occur using a 1,2,4-triazole containing 3 nitrogen atoms. The attachment of the propyl linker to the secondary nitrogen atom could lead to withdrawal of the halogen in the form of a hydrogen halide (Fig. 3(I)). EA showed that MCM-I-triaz and MCM-I-mpyr contained a small amount of halogen in their structures especially in comparison with the other materials, from which we can conclude that the salt formation did not took place, which was also reflected in their catalytic activity. Based on the results of elemental analysis, the quantity of heterocycle present in 1 g of material was calculated. MCM-I-triaz contained the highest amount of heterocycle attached (1.19 mmol/g for iodine-based materials). However, as mentioned above, triazole was likely attached through the secondary nitrogen, resulting in no salt formation. The amounts of attached methylimidazole, quinoline, methylpyrazole were similar (1 mmol/g). Another important parameter is the degree of quaternization ( DQ = n ( X ) n ( N ) ), which indicates the percentage of salt formed. It can be seen from the Table 1 that the quaternization was not successful in the cases of MCM-I-mpyr and MCM-I-triaz (8 resp. 13 %). In such cases, we can conclude that instead of quaternization of the nitrogen, the substitution proceeded on the secondary nitrogen atom with simultaneous withdrawal of iodine. Apart from these two mentioned cases, the quaternization was successful within the quaternization degree in the range 74–94 %. Comparing the type of halogen using the same heterocycle, 1-methylimidazole, we can say that the bromine-based material contained the highest amount of attached halogenopropyl linker, as well as the highest amount of attached 1-methylimidazole (Table 1). On the other hand, the modification of MCM-41 by a chloropropyl linker was the least successful. The degree of quaternization decreases in a row: Br > I > Cl. This trend corresponds with previous works [27,28]. Fig. 4 shows the thermogravimetric analysis of materials containing 1-methylimidazole quaternized with different halogens. TG analysis of MCM-I-mim and MCM-Br-mim had a similar trend. The curves showed the main decrease in the weight at approximately 250 °C. This decrease was attributed to the release of 1-methylimidazole. 1-Methylimidazole has a boiling point 198 °C, the higher temperature of its release was in accordance with its attachment to the structure by a stronger interaction and the physisorption was disproven. The weight decrease of MCM-Br-mim was higher (approx. 15 %) compared to MCM-I-mim (approx. 9 %). This decrease corresponded to the amount of 1-methylimidazole in the material based on the EA calculation. MCM-Cl-mim showed different trend, the main decrease in the weight started at about 150 °C. It pointed to the significantly lower stability of the material containing chlorine as halogen atom. The weight decrease in TGA curves corresponded to the amount of heterocycle attached to the support material (Fig. S1). The temperature of the weight decrease corresponded to the temperature higher than a boiling point of heterocycles. The presence of the plateau on the curves of MCM-I-quin and MCM-I-py might be explained by present interactions between heterocycle molecules, e.g. π-π stacking of aromatic rings of pyridine and quinoline. DRUV-Vis spectra of prepared materials are shown in Fig. S2. In the UV-Vis spectra of all materials (Fig. S2) the same trends were observed – a red shift of the characteristic bands in the case of N-heterocycles attached to the MCM-41 together with the formation of a new bands showing on the interaction of the support with the heterocycle. Interesting results possessed material MCM-I-triaz ( Fig. 5). As mentioned above, 1,2,4-triazole was most likely attached to the support material in multiple ways. Based on the literature [29], we can say that the band at ca. 220 nm can be attributed to 1,2,4-triazole in the form of a salt (π-π transitions). While other bands present may be attributed to the additional 1,2,4-triazole attachment options. Modification MCM-41 surface notably changed the surface characteristics as seen in Table 2. A slight decrease of specific surface area was noticeable after modification with a propyl linker (independently on the halogen atom). A significant decrease was then observed after quaternization with N-heterocycles and the decrease depended on the size of chosen heterocycle. At the same time, it is noticeable that a more significant decrease occurred with bromine-based materials compared to iodine-based ones. This phenomenon was already observed in our previous study [27]. Comparing the decrease of specific surface after attachment of pyridine, 1-methylimidazole and quinoline, we can see the lowest decrease in the case of pyridine, followed by methylimidazole and the highest decrease was in the case of quinoline. It corresponded to the loaded amount of heterocycle. Adsorption isotherms of prepared materials are shown in Fig. S3. XRD confirmed the preservation of MCM-41 structure even after modification by propyl linker and quaternization reaction with heterocycle (Fig. S4). 3.2 Catalytic testing Prepared heterogeneous salts of N-heterocycles were used as catalysts for cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide to obtain styrene carbonate ( Fig. 6). The cycloaddition reactions were carried out in solvent, and solvent-free arrangement. The influence of the halogen type and N-heterocycle used was observed. The cycloaddition reactions using the prepared materials proved to be highly selective as shown in Table 3. The selectivity to the desired styrene carbonate was almost 100 % in all cases. Fig. 7 shows the dependence of the conversion of styrene oxide on time using iodine-based catalysts with different nitrogen heterocycles. The catalysts MCM-I-mim and MCM-I-py proved to be the most effective under the given conditions, the achieved conversion was 88 and 75 %, respectively. The higher conversion using MCM-I-mim compared to MCM-I-py seemed to be in agreement with the results from the elemental analysis (Table 1) showing a smaller amount of attached iodine and pyridine in MCM-I-py. However, higher TON (Table 3) was calculated for MCM-I-py, so it mean that in the case of pyridinium modified MCM-41 the usage of active sites was higher than in the case of MCM-I-mim. This might be explained by a higher specific surface of MCM-I-py comparing to MCM-I-mim. Although MCM-I-quin had the highest degree of quaternization (94 %), and a comparable amount of attached heterocycle to methylimidazole (1 mmol/g), the conversion was only 67 % and TON was almost the smallest of all used materials. The lower conversion was probably due to the size of the quinoline molecule, and thus the steric reasons affected the catalytic activity. This statement was supported by the nitrogen sorption (Table 2) showing a relatively small specific surface area (129 m2/g). Interesting N-heterocycle used was 1,2,4-triazole. This compound had a low value of the quaternization degree (13 %), still surprisingly we obtained the desired styrene carbonate with a yield of 44 %, and significantly the highest TON. We suppose that the explanation lays in the highest loaded amount of triazole in the heterogeneous catalyst and a high use of halogen in the catalyst structure. As we showed in Table 1 MCM-I-mpyr possessed the lowest quaternization degree (8 %). Such low quaternization showed the formation of inactive specie thus low conversion of 11 % after 5 h was not surprising. High TON showed, as same as in the case of MCM-I-triaz, the high value of utilization of halogen in the catalyst structure. Even though that the high quaternization degree (87 %) and the UV-Vis of the MCM-I-pyrim indicated that an interaction between pyrimidine and the modified MCM-41 was present, a conversion of styrene oxide in the cycloaddition was only 15 % together with almost a lowest TON value. The possibility of the attachment of pyrimidine to the modified MCM-41 simultaneously through both nitrogen atoms in the molecule was considered Fig. 3. In such a case, the catalyst could block the pores of MCM-41, which would explain its low activity. Considering that the prepared salts of nitrogen-based heterocycles proved to be highly active for the cycloaddition reaction, a series of chiral materials for asymmetric cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide was prepared. These new materials, based on 4-substituted pyridine ((S)-py) (Fig. 2), were denoted MCM-I-(S)-py, and MCM-Br-(S)-py. The use of (S)-catalyst should affect the enantioselectivity of asymmetric cycloaddition in favor of (R)-cyclic carbonate [26]. The results are summarized in Table 4. The effect of temperature and pressure on the conversion and enantioselectivity was investigated. Despite lowering the temperature and pressure, no enhancement in enantiomeric excess was observed. The results demonstrated that these materials were somehow efficient (worse than pyridine based materials without chiral substituent) for cycloaddition reactions but did not meet our expectations for asymmetric reaction or kinetics resolution. For the 1-methylimidazolium salts the influence of the halogen type on the catalytic performance was observed. The iodine-based catalyst (MCM-I-min) proved to be the most active. The conversion of styrene oxide in the reaction containing MCM-I-mim was 88 %. Using MCM-Br-mim the achieved conversion was 81 % and it seemed to be almost similar to MCM-I-mim (Table 3). However, the TON values showed a decreasing trend of the catalyst activity following the halogen row. The chlorine-containing material showed the lowest activity of all prepared materials (TON of 15). Activity of prepared materials decreased in a row: I > Br > Cl, as we presented in our previous work [28]. These findings were supported by the literature [30], describing the relationship between the activity and the nucleophilicity of halogen. More nucleophilic halogens show a higher efficiency in the opening the epoxy ring. Table 5 shows the comparison of solvent and solvent-free arrangement as well. The solvent-free arrangement resulted in higher conversions compared to the experiments with solvent. This phenomenon could be expected due to the direct contact of the reagent and carbon dioxide. In the experiments with a solvent, the limiting was the solubility of carbon dioxide [27]. The advantage of heterogeneous catalysts in general is their easy separation from the reaction mixture and the possibility of repeated use. The possibility of reuse was demonstrated on the most efficient catalysts MCM-I-mim, MCM-I-py, and MCM-Br-mim. Materials were filtered from the reaction mixture, washed with toluene, dried overnight at 100 °C and reused. The elemental composition of reused material MCM-I-py is shown in Table 1. The obtained results showed no significant decrease of conversion and no decrease of selectivity after a second use, which was promising for their repeated use in large-scale reactions. 4 Conclusion Series of salts of N-heterocycles-based materials on support MCM-41 were prepared and used as novel catalysts in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide. The characterization of prepared materials confirmed the successful modification of MCM-41 by halogenopropyltri(m)ethoxysilane with subsequent reaction with N-heterocycle forming quaternary salt (MCM-X-R). Nevertheless, based on the results in the case of 3-methylpyrazole and 1,2,4-triazole, the formation of the quaternary salt probably did not primarily occur as in the other cases. Using prepared catalysts the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and styrene oxide was highly selective with 100 % selectivity to the desired styrene carbonate. We discussed the influence of the structure of heterogeneous catalyst (halogen type, N-heterocycle used) on its activity. Based on the characterization and catalytic results, a relation between the structure and catalytic activity of the used catalyst was discussed. The iodine-based catalyst was the most active in the cycloaddition reaction. The activity of the catalyst decreased in the row: I > Br > Cl. As expected, the presence of the solvent had an effect on the reaction course, and resulted in higher conversions under solvent-free arrangement. The highest conversion of styrene oxide (99 %) was achieved using catalyst with imidazolium salt (MCM-I-mim) under the following conditions: solvent-free arrangement, 10 mmol SO, 150 mg catalyst 120 °C, 1.2 MPa, 5 h. Due to the high activity of the pyridinium catalyst, chiral catalysts were also prepared using 4-substituted chiral pyridine. The prepared material was used for asymmetric cycloaddition to prepare (R)-styrene carbonate. However, no enantiomeric excess of the desired enantiomer was observed under the given conditions (25–120 °C, 1–1.2 MPa, 25 mL toluene, 5 h). coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the novel materials based on MCM-41-supported salts of N-heterocycles were prepared, and characterized by available methods (EA, DRUV, XRD, TGA, and nitrogen physisorption). The prepared materials were used as catalysts for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to epoxides. The model reaction for this study was the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide leading to the synthesis of styrene carbonate. The influence of the halogen type and N-heterocycle used was observed. The cycloaddition reactions using the prepared catalysts proved to be highly selective (almost 100 % in all cases). The most efficient catalyst was composed of (3-iodopropyl)trimethoxysilane and 1-methylimidazole, forming MCM-41supporting 1-methylimidazolium iodide with the conversion of styrene oxide 99 % (120 °C, 1.2 MPa, solvent-free, 5 h).

coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous catalysts based on salts of N-heterocycles for cycloaddition of CO2
